thread.title: Stormtroopers visit the Great Wall of China
thread.title_full: Stormtroopers visit the Great Wall of China - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Stormtroopers visit the Great Wall of China
text:
JASON LEE/REUTERS A horde of 500 stormtrooper replicas stood on the steps of the Great Wall of China. Even one of Earth's sturdiest defensive barriers proved to be no match for the Empire's imperial army.
A horde of 500 stormtrooper figures were stationed on the steps of the Great Wall of China on Tuesday to promote the highly anticipated upcoming blockbuster, "Star Wars: The Force Awakens."
The life-size soldiers held their trademark blasters as they menacingly stood shoulder-to-shoulder beneath one of the wall's watch towers.
Hundreds of fans flocked to the landmark to witness the stormtroopers' infiltration, and they were given free blue and red lightsaber replicas to commemorate the out-of-this-world occasion.
JASON LEE/REUTERS Some fans even dressed as "Star Wars" characters as they flocked to the Great Wall of China to see the stormtroopers. Mark Schiefelbein/AP The stormtroopers were there to promote the forthcoming “Star Wars: The Force Awakens” blockbuster. JASON LEE/REUTERS The new “Star Wars” does not have a release date in China yet. Previous Next Enlarge Meanwhile, billboards overlooking the wall displayed characters reading "The Force Awakens" in Chinese.
None of the original six "Star Wars" films aired in the highly regulated movie theaters in China — and the forthcoming seventh installment doesn't have a release date there yet either, according to The Hollywood Reporter.
The Force is slowly working its way into China, however, as Disney and Fox reportedly reached a deal earlier this month with Chinese streaming company Tencent to make the movies available online there.
Mark Schiefelbein/AP Fans were given replica lightsabers as the stormtroopers stood on the Wall behind them. "Star Wars: The Force Awakens" premieres in America on Oct. 18 — although many fans will have to wait a couple of days to see it.
Movie ticket giant Fandango crashed for hours on Oct. 19 soon after presale tickets went on sale, and the website has already set more than eight presale records.
AMC, meanwhile, sold out of tickets at more than 1,000 theaters within 12 hours of them becoming available.
Some of the fans lucky enough to knab opening day stubs have put them up for sale online — sometimes for upwards of $1,000 a pop.
